entries: An alkhazir doesn't require food, drink, or sleep. It suffers none of the frailty of old age and can't die of old age.

Initiated into the mysteries of science and the arcane, these individuals have learned the principles of creation, Azoth, and destruction, Alkahest, focusing on the latter. Working tirelessly with volatile substances, few destructive alchemists are left unscathed by their experimentations. Their body are wracked, missing fingers or entire limbs, and showing various types of burns. Their minds were often altered by the side effects of potion mixing or the toxic fumes that fills their laboratory. Still, nothing short of death will stop their work.

Inner alchemy is a less known branch of alchemy, akin to medicine. Those studying it focus on the effects of serums and tonics on the body, how it bolsters natural processes and suppresses limitations. To do so, they use their own body, or that of others, as one would an alembic, a mystical crucible of flesh and blood. Few survive the process of transformation, but those that do learn how to create wondrous substances in a heartbeat. Experimenters constantly push the boundaries of their body and ethic, they quickly lose touch with humanity as they transcend the limitations of the flesh.

entries.name: Crucible of Flesh
entries: One of the darkest uses of inner alchemy is known as the crucible of flesh, the practice of using the body, most specifically what is referred in alchemical treatises as anima, to create wondrous substances. Though little is really known about anima, it is thought to be the idealized life essence of a creature, contained in its vital fluids.

entries.name: Process
entries: The crucible of flesh can be performed by a creature proficient in Arcana, Medicine and with alchemist's supplies on a humanoid (including itself). A humanoid can willingly submit to the crucible of flesh, an agonizing process that takes at least 2 hours, otherwise the target must be restrained for the duration. At the end of the process, the target loses 50 hit points and an {@item oil of etherealness}, {@item oil of slipperiness}, {@item potion of longevity}, {@item sovereign glue}, or {@item universal solvent} is created. At the DM's discretion, other substances could be created. The target dies if reduced to 0 hit points by the process.

Chrysopoeia the transformation of base metals into gold has been a preeminent aspiration for alchemists. While many understand chrysopoeia as a metaphor for a mystical refinement, some practitioners adopted a literal interpretation and dedicate their lives to the fabled transformation. If the transformation has yet to be reliably performed or permanent, it is undeniable that the golden magisters have an unparalleled grasp on metallurgy and the alteration of metals.

The Great Work, as it is also called, is one of the most taxing and frustrating branches of alchemy, with some practitioner stagnating for decades. More importantly many oppose its success, and such researches are often outlawed, for the potential economic disaster they might incur should they succeed. Aside from the progress of science, insatiable greed drives most magisters.

entries.name: Eldritch Corruption
entries: The corrupting influence of the Far Realm can be insidious, subtly changing the mind and the body over months, or even years. It can also be brutal and sudden, racking the flesh and the mind in a matter of seconds, turning beasts and men into twisted things, now utterly alien and incomprehensible. Most creatures presented here simply fell victims of the corrupting influence, perhaps living in area suffused by warpstone (see the Warp Touched section of this book) or a nexus of eldritch energy. However, a selected few embraced it, seeking the dreadful revelations beyond the safety of the understandable and were rewarded. Whether it happened over night or was a long time coming, these mutated beings are paving the way for unconceivable horrors, their will subjugated by forces lurking in the great cosmic unknown.

entries.name: Method to Madness
entries: Bizarre and sinister cults worship the warped as messiahs, interpreting their behavior as the commands of superior beings. At first glance the wretched mutants are nothing more than mere monsters, driven hopelessly insane by the change. However, those with a discerning eye can see that there is a method to their madness, a hidden purpose that few of these creatures are even aware of, beckoning them through psionic whispers, astronomical events and dreams to gather and act in unusual ways. This does not mean that they always act in unison, for often they wage territorial wars against one another or exterminate their worshipers for no apparent reasons. Chaos and unpredictability rule when it come to the warped ones.

Each of these foul beings is a pawn part of a plan of unfathomable scale, a vessel for the will of eldritch gods and Elder Evils. To understand their motive is to leave our blessed island of ignorance and plunge into the black sea of infinity, to open the fabric of reality that few have the mental strength to withstand. Most flee from the deadly revelation into the peace and safety of their broken psyche, but a few form a new ego through the madness, facing the eldritch truth. Whatever drives the warped ones, here are a few possible {@i Grand Plans} by tiers of play:

entries.caption: Grand Plan
rows: Local

Find and kill those with the knowledge to oppose the aberrations; Commit ritual sacrifices and expose humanoids to warpstone's corruption; Leave inexplicable and disturbing evidence of aberrant influence.
Realm

Unearth warpstone idols, pillars, obelisks and other items of worship to cosmic entities; Spread the teaching and creation of tomes of eldritch magic to facilitate the summoning of aberrations and formation of cults; Destroy the elder seals, runestones or other means of protections that safeguard the world from cosmic entities.
Continent

Conduct an eldritch ritual to crash a warpstone meteor on the continent; Erect a warpstone megastructure of non-Euclidian geometry to become a permanent gate to the Far Realm; Gather enough warpstone and eldritch knowledge to alters space and time with unpredictable consequences.
World

Summon a balefire moon into orbit, mutating all life on the planet; Reveal the eldritch truth to all, driving the world into a murderous frenzy; Conjure a Great Old One to rule or destroy this reality.

entries: Warpstone corruption is absolute, it vitiates everything in its surrounding, including magic. A balespell is a corrupted spark of magical energy that latches onto a spellcaster when it casts a spell in the presence of warpstone or an eldritch nexus. Like a malign tumor a balespell feeds on magic, growing in strength with each spell cast by its host until it can completely overtake the body. The corrupted magic is incorporeal and invisible to the naked eye, but can be detected with spells like detect magic, revealing an aberrant magical signature. Once the balespell takes over, which can sometimes take months, the spellcaster suddenly burst in balefire, mutating into a dangerous abomination.

A newly created abomination will try to find other of its kind and create warp spawns. Ultimately, they build entire hives of these monstrosities, directing them to dig and erect strange temples to their abject idols. Wild rumors hint that it is possible to free someone from the balespell with the use of powerful magic and rituals. However it happens rarely due to the risks involved in such an attempt, unless done early. Those who are freed never truly recover as the soul of the former abomination is scarred and haunted for the rest of its days by waken visions and dreams of sheer cosmic terror. Most end their life shortly after. Death of the host is the most convenient way to end an abomination.

Warp lodestar are eldritch abomination with a giant bulbous mutated head. Once they were probably people, some psionic, astronomer or a medium maybe but whom or what exactly is now anyone's guess. Under the writhing mass of flesh, eyes, and maws that compose their head, it's possible to see a tall and vaguely humanoid body. From the side of their head far-reaching tentacles can sprout. Like beacons of warp and psionic energy they roam, seeking the resting places of Elder Evils, Great Old Ones or other site of eldritch significance, guiding aberrations and cultists like a glowing shepherd through the exodus. The lodestars are an affront to sanity, the focal points of the psionic energy that permeate from the cosmos. They constantly emit eerie telepathic singing that will drive anyone mad in but a few moments.

Obscuroth are horribly mutated humanoids often mistaken for mind flayers or vampires. They exemplify the corruption and dangers of the warpstone. During thunderstorms and astronomical events, such as a warpstone comet's appearance in the sky, these seemingly barbaric beings behave erratically. They engage in elaborate alien rites, carving grotesque idols and leaving strange, charged runes on cave walls. These incomprehensible scribbles are parts of eldritch spells and warnings on the forsaken stars. The ancient scripts and runes hold power that can harm the unwary or drive the sane to madness.

Although not very resilient, they are fast and dangerous, able to shred through armor with their claws. They feed on the blood of creature, sucking it through their mouth tentacles. This, combined with their ability to be invisible, and their psionic abilities, deter any sensible person to step into their territory. As nocturnal hunters they often make lairs to rest during daylight hours or store their kill for later consumption. They also sleep standing up, but are easily alerted, as even light footsteps will instantly awake them. They can be found in almost any environment corrupted by warpstone, but prefer deep mine shafts, dark forests, the Underdark or steep mountains with plenty of places to hide.

Many warlocks and cultists are granted spells and make pacts with elder gods, easily lured by the promises of power and rewards whispered through the great cosmic unknown. Those that delve deep into eldritch lore will eventually learn of the vozhark rites. It is known under many other names and variations, such as the Baneful Eclipse of Stillborn Atropus, The Forlorn Key of All-Seeing Bolothamogg, the Dismal Awakening of Great Cthulhu, or the Thousand Crimson Rebirth of Piscaethces. These ascension rituals are the lifegoals of the most ambitious cult leaders. But it takes an exceptional individual, quite mad and corrupted, to accept and survive the otherworldly gift, a warlock of immense power whose body has mutated over decades to finally cast the ritual and receive the alien blessing of the vozhark. A vozhark is the chosen herald, or talking puppet, of an Elder Evil in the Material Plane, a prime vessel for the eldritch might of its master. To face a vozhark is to stare at that which lurks beyond the stars, a glimpse at the true power of the cosmic horror peering through the flesh.

Although the outer gods share the ritual's knowledge quite willingly, to perform it successfully is a very different story. Its components are rare and precious, taking great resources and dedication to acquire. Once this by no means trivial matter has been taken care of, the ritual requires a favorable planetary alignment and the capricious stars do so every so often. It can take a few decades or centuries before it can be attempted in optimal conditions. Even then, there is a good chance that the mind and body of the aspiring vozhark will collapse under the arrival of the ancient being, requiring years of preparations from the warlock to survive the ordeal. Lastly, there is an even greater chance that the Elder Evil will simply be offended by the contact attempt and annihilate all participants here and now. Needless to say, the actual emergence of a vozhark is a rare thing to behold.

entries.name: Ascended Nature
entries: The vozhark doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep and it can resist crushing pressure, like that of a deep-sea trench or the void of space.

entries.name: Elder Evils
entries: What the Elder Evils are remains a mystery, but here are a few possible patrons for a vozhark:

{@i Atropus:}is an undead mass the size of a moon, drifting in space and laying waste to planets. Atropals are said to be cast-off detritus from its surface. The signs of its approach are unmistakable - the strengthening and rise of the undead.

{@i Bolothamogg:}is the darkness between the stars, the guardian of the outer dimensions of Far Realm, an unseizable force and the master of space-time. Past, present and future are one for him, as he sees all and knows all.

{@i Cthulhu:}is a colossal octopus-like entity. It lies in a death-like slumber beneath the oceans in the sunken city of R'lyeh. It dominates the will of mortals through dreams, visions and psionic might.

{@i Piscaethces:}is a perverse fertility deity that travels between infinite realities, spreading her seed as she moves from one world to another, uncaring about her creations. She is the creator of the aboleths.

entries.name: Consecrated Vozhark
entries: Vozhark are by no means all identical, in fact there probably never was one quite like the other. The Elder Evils are vastly different, and so are their vozharks. If you wish to personalize further a vozhark by maybe hinting at which Great Old One, Elder Evil or outer god inhabits it, use a consecrated vozhark. A consecrated vozhark has a challenge rating of 25 (75,000 XP) and additional traits and action options as indicated in each supplementary profile.

entries.name: Salvation by Murder
entries: When the fire of fanatism spreads across a nation, when times are hard and the people ask for a culprit that is nowhere to be found, when intolerance becomes the new norm, when bigotry and superstition take precedent over logic and science, this is when the terror of the witch hunters emerges. This radical religious order might come from almost any faith, but replace its dogma with anger and cultivated hatred, promising better times once all sinners have fallen. Killing heretics becomes the new way to salvation. But its promise is a lie, for it is a hungry beast that can never be sated, starving for hatred. It feeds on persecution. When a group of its enemy is eradicated it turns towards a new prey, always finding new groups to be smitten.

entries.name: Pyre and Faith
entries: The witch hunters appeal to the masses that feel belittled by elites, that blame their perceived misery on others, or those that hate the coming changes in their society. The uneducated, thugs, the greedy and sadists flock to it like moth to a flame, swelling its ranks. They are validated in their dark urges, normalized and endorsed in their cruel ways. They sack and steal, feeding the beast that grows in power with each group it consumes. Soon the pyres are lit for all contesters: intellectuals and minorities, practitioners of the arcane and clerics of other faith, artists, anyone that thinks out of the box.

When it comes to the witch hunters, the more special or remarkable you are, the more likely you will become a target. The magically inclined are always primarily targeted, for they inspired fear, envy and mistrust in the hearts of many. They make for ideal culprits, as few understand or sympathize with them and, sadly, history abound of examples were magic was used to unleash great evil. Whatever drives the witch hunters, here are a few possible {@i Grand Plans} by tiers of play:

entries.caption: Grand Plan
rows: Local
Destroy a holy site belonging to another religion or a powerful magic item; Kill/imprison a prominent religious figure from another faith; Seize the properties of arcane practitioners.
Realm
Establish its faith as the state religion and outlaw the worship of other deities; Outlaw the practice and teaching of arcane magic; Limit the rights of a particular race, subrace or gender.
Continent
Burn at the stake all arcane magic users and those with heretical behaviors; Instigate a theocracy ruling all aspects of life; Enact a miracle that will cause a grand scale religious conversion.
World
Exterminate all magical creatures and races; Cut the Prime Material Plane from all the other planes of existence; Banish all influence from heretical gods from the world.

entries.name: Deep Lead
entries: Lead as a metal is known to be a natural counter to magic. The thinnest sheet of lead can block the most powerful of divination, and it is often used as a mean to protect against magical prying. A purer form of lead, called deep lead or sometimes dimeritium, exists. It is a silvery metal with a hint of blue found only rarely in mineral veins. Deep lead is highly toxic, and those frequently exposed to it regularly experience migraines, respiratory diseases or even seizures. These effects are amplified for magical creatures and spellcasters that will instantly feel nauseous in its presence and intense physical pain at its contact. Witch Hunters rely heavily on deep lead and have integrated in their arsenal several devices based on that metal to face their most dangerous enemy: spellcasters.

Banishers were once powerful spellcasters, mages, warlocks or maybe clerics that fell into the hands of the witch hunters. However, these unfortunate souls did not meet a swift and painful end on a pyre, like so many of their brethren. Instead they were tortured relentlessly, poked with deep lead needles through the skull, locked for days in an iron maiden and some other gruesome methods. The goal was not torture, but to kill the spark of magic in them, to turn them into a banisher, an antimagic weapon for the witch hunters. This process made them irremediably mad, destroying their mind as surely as their magic.

Banishers constantly try to fill the magic void within them, draining the Weave with no way of giving it shape or form. Reminiscence of their spellcraft only comes now in raw and violent burst of force energy. This makes them notoriously unstable, a magical siphon that could explode at any time. For this reason, most are constantly chained and never see the light of the day, locked down in some deep vault until there is no other solution left but to use them. When they are freed, they are transported in armored stagecoach and bound, under a heavy witch hunter escort.

Indoctrinated to the extreme, flagellants are crazed zealots that expiate their sins with unrestrained fanatism. They flay their own flesh to show they devotion, as penance for the sins of the world and to quell impure thoughts. Long downtrodden, they always come from poor background and are the first to pass judgment on any who differ from their view of the world.

They care not for their lives, throwing themselves into the fray in shocking gestures of self-sacrifice and repentance. To become a martyr of the faith is the highest honor that flagellants can aspire for, hopefully taking down with them many heretics. They firmly believe in their divine mission of cleansing and redemption, and their conviction gives them a courage that borders upon insanity as they charge against impossible odds.

entries.name: Bands of Flagellants
entries: Flagellants tend to operate in bands, gathering to listen to the hateful preaching of the inquisitors and scouring the countryside and cities to root out the heresy. More often than not they end up persecuting innocent pellars, herbalists and faithhealers than finding any real dangerous arcanist. To represent the roving bands, we recommend using the {@i crowd} with the {@i fanatics} template (see "crowd" in the chapter Nonplayer Characters of this book).

A witchfinder general is an individual of exceptional faith and willpower, with a keen mind to find witches and heretics. After countless interrogations, numerous arrests and executions, they have been promoted to the elite of the witch hunters. Over their career they have learned to never underestimate their opponent and the existence and intricacies of the weave of magic. With a combination of knowledge, immense hatred and resolve, they are able to temporarily nullify its presence.

When they are not busy with the burden of command and global coordination, they often lead important hunts or are tasked to find especially slippery heretics that have eluded capture for a while. Few tricks can still surprise them, and they are well accustomed to the ruses and artifices of spellcasters. Their badge of office is the cruel pincer staff, a polearm ending by a pincer with serrated edges. They use it to restrain heretics before branding them or give time to their allies to subdue them with deep lead shackles.

Trained to fight magic users and recognize the signs of the occult, the witch hunters are the bane of witches. Ruthless, they target all that show the slightest sign of magical talent, heretical knowledge, fiendish corruption or simply gets in their way, using brutal torture to extort confessions. Having studied various types of lore, they can recognize the signs of rituals, component pouches and spellcasting focus. Supported by their order, they carry with them a number of devices to help them in their task such as deep lead shackles, weapons and bombs.

Witch hunters are seen by many as sanctioned cold-blooded killers, the hounds of the temple. They venture the world to apprehend and hold summary trials for magic-users and nefarious creatures. The verdict is always the same: death by fire. Many believe that they speak and act on behalf of the clergy, but in truth not all witch hunter are affiliated or even religious. They are more of a mercenary group and their actual legitimacy is pretty nebulous, but questioning it openly is a sure way to be branded a heretic.

variantrule.name: Warpstone Intensity
entries: Warpstone twists and corrupts, its alien presence warps reality in ways that science or magic cannot explain. Land suffused by Warpstone can show different degrees of corruption, from deadly wasteland where only death awaits, to strange countries populated by mutants and mongrelfolks.

entries.caption: Warpstone Intensity
rows: Faint
Every number of months equal to a character Constitution Modifier passed in the area; DC 10
Weak
Every number of weeks equal to a character Constitution Modifier passed in the area; DC 13
Moderate
Every number of days equal to a character Constitution Modifier passed in the area; DC 15
Severe
Every number of hours equal to a character Constitution Modifier passed in the area; DC 17
Deadly
Every number of minutes equal to a character Constitution Modifier passed in the area; DC 20

items.name: Faint Intensity
items.entry: In many parts of the world, regions suffer from the lingering influence of Warpstone. Such effects are not always obvious, and only a trained eye can detect the signs of corruption. When a region is known for its precious stones mines, inexplicably "haunted" areas, aberrations attacks or malformed children, there is always a chance that Warpstone formations are hidden beneath the surface or that small meteors crashed in the area long ago.

items.name: Weak Intensity
items.entry: These lands only show a few signs of corruption, Warpstone deposits are probably located deep beneath the surface, or pockets of corruption scattered across the land. Inhabitants of these regions tend to be born with mutations, their offspring showing the same malformations over generations. Weather in the area is quick to change, often unpredictable, and the wildlife and flora exhibit signs of corruption as well, including strange species unique to the region.

items.name: Moderate Intensity
items.entry: Corruption taint such region anywhere you look. The air itself has a coppery taste, and the weather is always harsh and gloomy. Mutated creatures roam the land, showing advanced signs of corruption, making any assumption on their initial species difficult at best. Warpstone deposits are close to the surface, with probably some mineral veins exposed here and there. Such land would typically only have a handful of minor settlements, struggling for survival amongst the aberration and mutated horrors that own this territory.

items.name: Severe Intensity
items.entry: In these lands, the wind cuts like daggers and the ground is hard as iron, making it impossible to sustain any kind of life. Freak weather always rage over the region, while the landscape is nightmarish, ravaged by earthquakes, pits of balefire and storms of eldritch energies. Deposits of Warpstone can frequently be found on the surface, surrounded by precious gemstones. Illusions and tears in reality constantly deceive the senses, making navigation hazardous at best and weighting heavily on one's sanity. The only kind of creature encountered are deadly aberrations and the ones driven mad by the cursed landscape.

items.name: Deadly Intensity
items.entry: Such areas are usually small, probably the crash site of the meteor itself or an extremely dense deposit of Warpstone. The sickening green glow emitted is visible from miles around. Apart from aberrations, nothing can survive here for more than a couple of minutes. Each minute while present in the area, a creature other than an aberration, construct or undead take 10 (3d6) necrotic damage. A creature hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. A creature becomes a Warp Spawn if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.

variantrule.name: Warp touch
entries: One of the worst effects of raw chaos and dissolution, the malady known as Warp Touch horribly twists the flesh of an infected creature as the body collapses under the unbearable weight of corruption and is infused with the raw power of change, forcing all manner of strange and disturbing transformations. Once the first mutation takes hold, the creature that was once now faces the inevitable dissolution of his mind and will, becoming something less than yet more than mortal. The fate that awaits nearly all surviving mutants is to become a warp spawn, a gibbering abomination existing only to spread its corruption.

When a character falls victim to this disease, roll immediately on the Warp Touch table and the infected creature suffers one level of {@condition exhaustion}. At the end of each long rest, an infected creature must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, with disadvantage if it suffers from a level of {@condition exhaustion}. On a failed save, the character must roll again on the warp touch table. If the character rolls a mutation it already has, it can decide to gain a level of {@condition exhaustion} or to roll again until it gets a new mutation. A character that dies out of {@condition exhaustion} becomes immediately a warp spawn.

Some mutations grant boons and flaws, during a long rest, an affected character must check if its flaws awakes, making a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the flaws of the character comes into play, as described on the mutation. On a successful save, the character keeps control of its mutation.

Lesser restoration or similar spells cannot cure the disease, only a heal spell is powerful enough to erase the influence of the disease and purge the flesh and soul of all traces of corruption. A creature that turned into a warp spawn can only be saved with the intervention of a wish spell. Aberrations, constructs and undeads are immune to the Warp Touch.

entries.caption: Warp Touch
rows: The body of the character mutates horribly; the character turns into a warp spawn and is placed under the DM control. If this is the first mutation rolled, the character gains a level of {@condition exhaustion} instead.

Multiples sets of eyes appear on the character's body. It has now advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight. Flaw: A nearby creature can see through the extra eyes of the character, as per the clairoyance spell.

The character grows extra, useless and deformed, arms and tentacles that sometimes move of their own accord. The character has advantage on Strength ability checks. Flaw: The extra appendices become uncontrollable, as per the evard's black tentacles spell, centralized on the character, moving with him and with a spell save DC 15.
The tongue of the character grows extremely long or twisted. It can now speak Deep Speech. Flaw: The character can only speak Deep Speech for the next hour.

Vestigial wings grow on the character's belly, head or back. The character can fall down up to 30 feet without taking falling damage and can land on its feet. Beyond that, falling distance is reduced by 30 feet.
The back of the character curves and grows a hump. The character has disadvantage on Dexterity ability checks and its speed is reduced by 10 feet.

The head of the character grows disproportionally and a nightmarish face appears at the back of it. The character can cast the spell detect thoughts once per long rest. Charisma is its spellcasting ability for the spell. Flaw: The character suffers from a short-term madness.

Balefire, harmless blue and green flames, sometimes runs down the skin of the character. The characters knows the fire bolt cantrip. Charisma is its spellcasting ability for the spell. Flaw: Flammable objects that aren't being worn or carried within 30 feet of the character catch fire.
The Warp Touch stops. The character keeps all previously acquired mutations but is cured of the disease.

entries.name: Lure Weed
entries: Lure weed is a mutated plant that only grows in water sources tainted by Warpstone. The weed itself is easy to spot, with a long stem ending on bioluminescent leaves. While the weed itself is pleasing to look at, its true value lies in the remedy that can be brewed out of it.

items.name: Warp Touch Remedy:
items.entry: A character that has proficiency with Alchemist's Tools or Herbalism Kit, and access to the proper equipment, can prepare a remedy with lure weed flowers. The remedy has a value of 40gp when it comes to crafting (see crafting rules p.187 of the Player's Handbook). Once ingested, the Warp Touch stops. The character keeps all previously acquired mutations but is cured of the disease.

variantrule.name: Wraith Extra Powers
entries: Ghost and wraith were once people, with their own personalities, dreams, hopes and flaws. When they died some of their abilities carried in undeath. You can add the following Innate Spellcasting options to any kind of ghost, specters or wraith to make it more unique. These abilities are affecting the CR of the creature as indicated. Please note that, in some case, the ability might be more powerful or useful when combined with some other feature already included in the creature's profile. To know the spell DC of the powers refer yourself to the Spell DC table.

entries.name: Entropy
entries: By essence, ghost are entropic creatures, forces of decay infused with necrotic energies. The creature can use the {@spell bestow curse}, {@spell ray of enfeeblement} and {@spell vampiric touch} spells once per short rest.

entries.name: Gravetouched
entries: Unexplainable cold spots are often associated with haunted places and many ghost do have the power to summon supernatural cold. The creature can use the ray of frost cantrip at will and the sleet storm and cone of cold spells once per short rest.

entries.name: Madness
entries: Many ghosts are utturly mad, driven insane by an eternity in constant sorrow. Some of them have the ability to project that madness. The creature can use the {@spell crown of madness}, {@spell confusion} and {@spell fear} spells once per short rest.

entries.name: Supernatural Lockdown
entries: The creature is able to lockdown a place, preventing anyone to enter or leave it without powerful magic. The ghost can use the spell {@spell arcane lock} at will and the {@spell mordenkainen's private sanctum} and {@spell wall of force} spells once per short rest.

entries.name: Telekinesis
entries: Many ghost have the ability to move object and people with the sheer strength of their will. The creature can use the cantrip {@spell mage hand} at will and the spell {@spell telekinesis} once per short rest.

entries.name: Ubiquitous
entries: Some ghost are known to haunt multiple places at once, or to be able to appear instantly from a location to another, even when separated by great distances. The creature can use the {@spell simulacrum} and {@spell teleport} spell once per short rest to move between places related to its story.

entries.name: Warp
entries: Many ghosts have the ability to manipulate reality, shapping it to reflect the constant pain they are experiencing. The creature can use the {@spell animate object}, {@spell seeming} and {@spell silence} spells once per short rest.

entries.caption: Innate Spellcasting - Spell DC
rows: 1st
5th
11th
17th
20th

entries.name: Genesis of Evil
entries: What makes a villain? Some people are simply born with the seed of evil in them, subject to dark urges from the very moment they are born. Others are unable to relay to others, fundamentally broken and committing terrible acts without even blinking. However, very few people are born truly evil, most reacted to the way society shaped them and motivated their acts, others were forged by circumstances that scared them deeply, sending them spiraling down a dark abyss or were simply bent on survival, no matter the cost. Often, inside each villain there is a victim, but some simply say that you either die a hero, or live long enough to see yourself become the villain...

entries.name: The Grand Plan
entries: Characters appearing in this section are villains centralized around a theme and made to be used as evolving antagonists, progressing alongside the party. They work as individual or organization, each of them has a Grand Plan and smaller schemes to reach it. The Grand Plan will likely change in scope, as the villain's reality and ambition evolve with its power and capacities. A low CR villain is more focused on the local affairs, while a high CR villain will likely affect an entire nation, or even the entire campaign world.

entries.name: Mounting Threat
entries: Villains or groups of villains don't typically sit in their lair doing nothing or waiting patiently for the party to come and find them. This type of behavior might be suited for some individuals, but most villains will pursue their own agenda, however basic or elaborate it may be. As the party progresses, so does their foe. Each time the party completes an important quest, takes an extended rest period or completes a story arch, roll or choose on the scheme table what scheme the villain is currently trying to achieve (or its organization and agents, if any). If the party learns of their scheme, it could be a great opportunity for them to interfere.

Parts of this section are revolving around the idea that your villain(s) will face the party multiples times and increase in power. This requires preparation, as players may go for your main antagonist earlier than you expected and try to get rid of them for good. Clever or instinctive villains will not let themselves be cornered if they can avoid it and will have several escape plans once the odds turn against them. If you opt for an organization of villains this is less of a challenge, as killing a specific individual or destroying a location might not be enough to end the threat.

Consider a few potential means of escape for your villain before an encounter, using magic (teleportation, illusion, invisibility, darkness spells, scrolls or potions) or mundane means (planned cave-in, secret passage, reinforcements, risky path where the party might hesitate to follow, etc.). If your villain does fall, it is not necessarily their end, especially for villains with allies that have access to resurrection magic or serve a powerful master.

entries.caption: Scheme
rows: {@i Distract (roll again for its true scheme)} - Threatens player's assets, allies or loved ones; Unleash seemingly random danger and mayhem; Destabilizes opposed government or faction; Acquires/establishes fake new lair; Makes a public appearance and demonstration of its power.

{@i Strengthen} - Recruits multiple hirelings or a highly skilled ally; Infiltrates/corrupts a spy in an opposed faction; Acquires a useful magic item; Destroy/attacks a rival faction; Develop the defenses of its lair.
{@i Progress} - Works towards the next step of its Grand Plan. See each section for suggested Grand Plan ideas.

{@i Setback} - A part of the villain's past is unwittingly revealed; An ally of the villain is killed or betrays them; A natural or magical disaster damages the villain's lair; A hint of the villain's Great Plan is revealed; Unforeseen complications prevent the villain to accomplish anything.
